title: Dante and its alternatives
content:
There seems to be disagreement about the quality of the Monotype Dante font. Some say it is well digitized, some find the hot-metal version much superior.   
Experts! What is your final word on this subject and are there any alternatives to Dante that would look very similar to the hot-metal version?

 [‹ Print Logo resource?](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428201229/http:/typophile.com/node/5217 "Go to previous forum topic") [What font is 'exotic' and 'adventurous'? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20150428201229/http:/typophile.com/node/5268 "Go to next forum topic")
author: aku_ankkuli

comments.content: both are very well drawed, but i like a little more hot metal

The Stamperia Valdonega in Verona, now run my Giovanni Mardersteig's son, Martino, has its own digital version of Dante. This is really splendid, has a range of optical sizes, and is much superior to the Monotype version. Also, it is based on the foundry metal original, not Monotype's hot metal version. It is not available for license.   
   
The Monotype digital version is not a bad font -- it is better than many digital incarnations of metal types and has a reasonably good weight -- but is pales in comparison to the Stamperia Valdonega version.
"Stamperia Valdonega" also sounds way more impressive than "Monotype".

Yikes! I've never seen the Stamperia Valdonega version in a PDF before, only at text size in print. It's pretty scary when you zoom in on the outlines.   
   
The SV is used only internally at the press.
